title: Opinion: Simone Biles makes more history, wins fifth all-around title at worlds
text:
CLOSE

STUTTGART, Germany – There really does need to be a Simone Division.

Simone Biles had her fifth title at the world championships wrapped up midway through the meet Thursday, and won by her largest margin ever. It was her 22nd medal at the world championships, putting her just one from the record of Belarus’ Vitaly Scherbo – who had two more events to collect his, mind you.

Only Japan’s Kohei Uchimura, with six, has more world titles.

After doing her final pose, a grinning Biles pretended to drop a mic. As she should.

In the lead-up to the Rio Olympics, Biles’ U.S. teammates would joke about the “Simone Division,” an acknowledgment of just how much better she was than everyone else.

A year before the Tokyo Games, the gap has only gotten wider. Biles finished 2.1 points ahead of China’s Tang Xijing, who only made the all-around after Liu Tingting scratched. Angelina Melnikova of Russia was third. American Sunisa Lee, competing in her first world championships, finished eighth.

Biles had a slim 0.033 lead over Belgium’s Nina Derwael after the first rotation, giving faint hope to anyone hoping for an upset. But she shut that down real quick on uneven bars.

Yes, her least-favorite and “weakest” event.

The new skills Biles has added on floor, vault and balance beam in the last year get most of the attention – rightly so because they have pushed the boundaries of the sport. But improvement on bars under coach Laurent Landi, who coached Madison Kocian to a world title on the event in 2015, has probably been the most dramatic.

She moves between the bars with confidence, and her dismount – a double-twisting, double somersault – was huge. She got several feet above the upper bar yet landed with a solid thud, her feet not moving an inch.

Her score, a 14.733, was the third-highest of the day on the event, and widened her lead over Derwael to more than a point. 1.033, to be exact. And there was no way Derwael was going to get any closer, having started on uneven bars, her best event.

Balance beam has been the curse of many a gymnast at these world championships, but Biles has been solid every routine. Though she didn’t do her new double-double dismount – why would she when the International Gymnastics Federation isn’t going to value it fairly? – it didn’t matter.

She moves across the beam, which is a mere 4 inches wide and 4 feet off the ground, with more assuredness than most mere mortals walk on flat ground. She landed her aerial series as if to say, “Oh, is that supposed to be hard?”

Biles had a slight balance check on her split leap, but that’s like quibbling over a brush stroke on a Picasso. Her score of 14.633 increased her lead to 1.3 points, with Tang now in second.

That left only floor exercise, where Biles is the reigning world and Olympic champion. She did her new triple-twisting, double somersault pass to open, getting such height she had to take a step out of bounds. But it was minor compared with all of the difficulty she packs into the routine.

She almost fell backward on her final pass, but managed to stay upright.
description: It was Simone Biles' 22nd medal at the world championships, putting her just one from the record of Belarus’ Vitaly Scherbo.
